user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_size_:
```c
static lfs_soff_t lfs_file_size_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    (void)lfs;

#ifndef LFS_READONLY
    if (file->flags & LFS_F_WRITING) {
        return lfs_max(file->pos, file->ctz.size);
    }
#endif

    return file->ctz.size;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_file_size_:
typedef int32_t  lfs_soff_t
...
typedef struct lfs_file {
    struct lfs_file *next;
    uint16_t id;
    uint8_t type;
    lfs_mdir_t m;

    struct lfs_ctz {
        lfs_block_t head;
        lfs_size_t size;
    } ctz;

    uint32_t flags;
    lfs_off_t pos;
    lfs_block_t block;
    lfs_off_t off;
    lfs_cache_t cache;

    const struct lfs_file_config *cfg;
} lfs_file_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the provided function lfs_file_size_ and the related type definitions. There are no calls to memcmp (nor to strcmp/strncmp or other standard library string-comparison functions), no usage of char* or any pointer to null-terminated strings, and no inclusion of string.h in the shown fragments. The function only inspects integer/size fields and flags and returns numeric sizes/positions. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that could violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 (using memcmp to compare null-terminated strings), so nothing needs to be investigated for that rule.
